[[Determination]] | footnotes = }} School students in [[Australia]], [[New Zealand]] and [[Fiji]] often play a style of '''handball''' (Also known as four square or - square, with the number in the latter determined by the number of players) that is different from nearly all other types of [[handball (disambiguation)|handball]]. The game is played at [[Recess (break)|recess]], lunch or before and after school. It can also be played at home or anywhere that has a hard surface and at least one line. It has quick set-up time and simple rules, contributing to its popularity. [[File:Spaldeen.jpg|thumb|The most common handball, a [[Spaldeen]].]] Unlike most types of handball, this version does not incorporate a wall, instead relying on lines on the ground. A typical handball court is a square split into four, usually by painted lines or [[expansion joint]]s, with the highest and most prestigious position on the court being Ace, followed by King, Queen, then Dunce. The most radical change from [[American handball]] is that players must bounce the ball (usually a tennis ball or a high bounce ball) in their own square first, until it is allowed to bounce into another player's square. Each player, if the ball bounces within their square, must then hit the ball with their hand, have it bounce within their own square once, and then an opponent's square. Failure to do so results in the player being relegated to the lowest position on the court, or the last of the players waiting to enter the court. Due to the social nature of handball at school and the simplicity of playing, many variations to the rules can occur. For example, one group may play in a square of four while the next school over, the game is played in a straight line of six squares, radically altering the game. In addition, some variations of the game allow for the head or feet to be used to return the ball. As a result, this article only covers the most common rules and is not representative of every variation. In other words, the rules may vary between schools, but basic rules usually remain the same. ==Rules== === Basic rules === * A game must have at least two players. * The person in the leading square, ''''serves'''' the ball, bouncing once within their square before entering an opponent's square. * Once the serve is complete, the receiver must hit the ball to another player. * The ball must be hit so that it bounces in the player's own square on the first bounce, and into another player's on the second bounce. * If the first bounce lands on the line and is not a ''''full'''' or a ''''double'''', it is known as ''''line''''. When ''''line'''' is called the point is replayed. * If the second bounce of the ball lands on a line between their and another player's square, the ball is deemed to have bounced in the other player's square, thus play continues. * If an outside object interferes with the play, the point will be replayed. * When a player is ''''out'''', they must proceed to the lowest square, or to the end of the line of players waiting to enter the court. Players on the court who were of a lower position each move up a square. The player is 'out' when they have committed any of the following: * '''Full:''' when the ball lands in another player's square on the first bounce, the player has 'fulled' or has hit a 'full'. * '''Out:''' when the ball lands outside of the court, the last person who touched the ball or the last court the ball touched is out. * '''Double:''' when the ball bounces twice in a person's square, the person who is in that square is out. Usually known as 'double', 'double bounce'. * '''Double touch:''' when the ball is touched twice in a row by the same person. * '''Grabs/Carry:''' when the ball is held or scooped instead of a clean hit. * '''Interference:''' if a player interferes with another player, they are out. * '''Foul:''' when the ball bounces in players square and is not returned to another players square via a hit (the ball then goes out or into another players square). [[File:Handball Shots.jpg|449x449px|Getting out in handball usually is caused by (anti-clockwise starting top-right): Out, Doubles, Full. The four image is what normal play looks like.|thumb]] === Variations === Due to the rules of handball varying from school to school, the following variations have developed: '''Lines:''' depending on the location or age-group, the definition of a 'line' changes and their role in the game also changes. Generally, in younger age groups, if the ball lands on any line separating two opponents on any bounce, it is treated as if it were a line and the point 'replayed'. However, depending on the school or institution, lines can be treated as if they are a part of an opponent's square, thus the game will always continue if the ball hits the line. In instances where the ball may fall on a line separating two squares on the full, the square that the majority of the ball bounces in is consider to be where the ball landed. On the opposite end of the spectrum, some games will deem a ball to be 'out' if it hits any line that does not border another square. '''Outs:''' in some locations, due to surrounding objects, a handball court may 'extend' onto walls, the roof or external objects such as poles, lockers and windows. In this variation, commonly known as ''''rebounds'''', the ball can bounce off, hit or roll along any other surface near the court as long as it is returned to the court. In this game, the ball is only considered to bounce when it hits the floor of a player's square. '''Grab:''' in many establishments, the definition of a 'grab' is hotly debated. In some instances, a grab is considered to be any motion when the ball is held. In others, a grab is outlawed however a ''''cradle'''', a low bouncing shot where the ball is balanced in the palm, is allowed. In some games, especially for lower aged groups, grabbing the ball may be allowed. '''Interference:''' in some versions of the game, interference will resulting in the point being replayed. In other versions a player may commit a ''''ghost'''' without repercussions, where a play attempts to put another player off by moving any part of their body near the ball as the player attempts to hit it. '''Readiness of the players:''' in some games, players must be fully ready before the player in the top square can serve. In other styles, the player must only be in the square to be considered 'ready'. Finally, in some versions a player may serve at any time, as long as they call ''''ever-ready'''' as a warning to players to prepare to commence the point. '''Serving:''' In most games, as serve is conducted by the player it the highest square throwing the ball into the other square. In other variations, the player must hit the ball out of their hand to make a serve. It is common in games that a player call ''''decent'''' on a serve that not easy to hit, and the point is retaken. '''Cherries:''' in younger age groups, a game may develop where 'fulls' are allowed, to make play easier. '''Playing on:''' In the majority of games the ''''first-fault'''' style is used, where - when a player gets out and play continues or multiple outs occur - the play is stopped and the first person to get out is deemed to be out. In other games, ''''two-play-on-play'''' is used, where the point may continue if two hits by two other players occur. == The court == Even though each part of the court is referred to as a 'square', a square can be any shape or size. Its edges or 'lines' can be marked with any material, including: paint, expansion joints, cracks, chalk or points where the square meets an object such as a wall or locker. Commonly, the court is either a bitumen or concrete surface. Depending on the school, the squares will either be labelled Ace, King, Queen and Dunce or King, Queen, Jack and Dunce.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mooreteachingtips.com/wp-content/uploads/handball-rules.pdf|title=Four Square Handball Rules|last=|first=|date=|website=Moore Teaching Tips|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} [[File:Handball4.jpg|thumb|263x263px|A paint marked handball court]] == In popular culture == In popular culture, handball has grown popularity in the current '[[meme]]' culture. In Australia, former prime minister [[Kevin Rudd]] released a video in March, 2013 of him playing handball at [[Brisbane State High School]].{{Citation|last=Kevin Rudd|title=Playing handball at Brisbane State High School|date=2013-03-10|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RoVua2LBeDU|accessdate=2017-10-31}} This triggered a growth of popularity in handball, and lead to him being ingrained into 'handball meme' culture. In late November, 2017, Kevin Rudd played handball with students in a school in Brisbane, and the accompanying video - claiming he is the "king of handball' - reached 40,000 views on [[Facebook]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/handball420/videos/1951839748406160/|title=Handball Memes|website=www.facebook.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-31}} Handball is also the main theme of the children's television series, ''[[Handball Heroes]]'', which aired on [[ABC Me]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/programs/handball-heroes/|title=Handball Heroes|website=ABC Television|language=en-AU|access-date=2017-10-31}} ==References== [[Category:Sport in New Zealand]] [[Category:Wall and ball games]] [[Category:Sport in Australia]] [[Category:Sport in Fiji]] [[Category:Sports originating in Australia]]

{{Infobox publisher | name = Harvey Thriller | founded = [[1965 in comics|1965]] | founder = | status = defunct, [[1967 in comics|1967]] | image = | headquarters = [[New York City]] | country = [[United States]] | keypeople = [[Joe Simon]] | parent = [[Harvey Comics]] | divisions = | publications = [[Comic books]] | topics = | genre = Superhero | imprints = | url = }} '''Harvey Thriller''' was a [[comic book]] imprint used by [[Harvey Comics]] for their brief foray into publishing super heroes and other non-'kiddie' comics in the mid-1960s. Overseen by [[Joe Simon]], all the titles featured work by many well-known creators, including [[Jack Kirby]], [[Bob Powell (comics)|Bob Powell]], [[Wally Wood]], [[Otto Binder]], and the earliest known work by [[Jim Steranko]].
== History == === Thrill Adventure === While Harvey Comics has for decades been known for their many kids' comics, such as [[Casper the Friendly Ghost]], [[Richie Rich (comics)|Richie Rich]], etc., they have published other kinds of comics over the years. From 1955 to 1962, most of their non-kid comic output was done under the "Thrill Adventure" line, under the editorship of [[Joe Simon]], after which they stopped publishing any non-kid comics.
=== Harvey Thriller === In the mid-1960s, with the [[camp (style)|camp]] craze created by the [[Batman (TV series)|Batman television series]], Harvey approached Joe Simon again to oversee a new line of comics, mainly [[superhero]]es, but with [[science fiction]]/[[fantasy]] stories thrown in as well. They also continued the Thrill Adventures title [[Warfront (comics)|Warfront]], after a 7-year hiatus.
The line started off with one-shots ''Unearthly Spectaculars'' #1, ''Thrill-O-Rama'' #1, ''Blast-Off'' #1, and ''Warfront'' #36 in October 1965, using work that was apparently done for the 1950s Thrill Adventure line. The next issues would not come out until almost a year later in September 1966. Along with the new titles were two reprint titles for [[Fighting American]] and [[The Spirit]], which did include new stories for these characters. All the titles ended by March 1967; unpublished work for ''Jigsaw'' #3 and ''Thrill-O-Rama'' #3 may exist.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}}

=== Harvey Thriller === *''Blast Off'' (1965) #1 (3 Rocketeers, stuff intended for ''Race for the Moon'' #4) *''Double-Dare Adventures'' (1966–67) 2 issues (Bee-man, Glowing Gladiator, Magic Master) *''[[Fighting American]]'' (1966) 1 issue *''[[Jigsaw (Harvey Comics)|Jigsaw]]'' (1966) 2 issues *''[[Spirit (comics)|Spirit]]'' (1966–67) 2 issues *''[[Spyman]]'' (1966–67) 3 issues *''Thrill-O-rama'' (1965–66) 3 issues (Man in Black-Fate, Pirana #2-on) *''Unearthly Spectaculars'' (1965–67) 3 issues (Tiger Boy, Jack Q Frost, 3 Rocketeers, Miracles, Inc, Earthman) *''[[Warfront (comics)|Warfront]]'' (1965–67) #36-39 (Dynamite Joe, Lone Tiger in 2nd issue)

In [[film theory]], the '''institutional mode of representation''' ('''IMR''') is the dominant mode of film construction, which developed in the years after the turn of the century, becoming the norm by about 1914. Although virtually all films produced today are made within the IMR, it is not the only possible mode of representation. Other possibilities include the '''primitive mode of representation'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA-->, which was dominant before being replaced by the IMR; certain [[avant-garde film]]s that constitute a “[[deconstructionist]]” challenge to the IMR; and various non-western modes, notably pre-war Japanese film,<ref>Noël Burch (1979). ''[http://hdl.handle.net/2027/spo.aaq5060.0001.001 To the Distant Observer: Form and Meaning in Japanese Cinema]''. Berkeley: University of California Press.</ref> that were possible before the IMR became the worldwide norm. [[Classical Hollywood cinema]] is the dominant style within the IMR, but other styles such as [[art house]], [[independent film|independent]], and most (current) foreign styles fall no less under the IMR.
==Overview== The concept was developed by [[Noël Burch]] in his 1969 book ''Praxis du cinéma''. Burch’s goal is to show that the IMR was a class-determined practice, developed out of the bourgeois desire for totalizing illusionistic representation. [[André Bazin]] had identified the “myth of total cinema,” or a constant desire to represent reality as completely as possible, which he claimed as the root of cinema innovations (both technology such as sound, color, and widescreen as well as techniques such as more elaborate editing). Burch, on the other hand, argues that IMR is no more elaborate or realistic a system than its alternatives.
The IMR is characterized by the attempt to create an entirely closed fictional world on screen. The audience is completely imaginatively involved in the film, instead of being distant from it and seeing it as an object to be examined. Burch argues that the key to the IMR is "spectatorial identification with a ubiquitous camera."<ref>Noël Burch (1986). "Primitivism and the Avant-Gardes: A Dialectical Approach" in ''Narrative-Apparatus-Ideology'', ed. Phil Rosen. New York: Columbia UP. p. 491</ref> Various techniques (often referred to as the “language of cinema”) were developed in order to accomplish this identification:
* Films are constructed out of a sequence of shots, each of which presents the viewer with one clear piece of information. In contrast to the Primitive Mode, IMR therefore uses close-ups. * A three-dimensional space is created, using Renaissance rules of [[Perspective (graphical)|perspective]] as well as new [[cinematic techniques]] such as [[editing]] and [[lighting]]. To preserve the illusion of spatial integrity, which was lost with the introduction of close-ups, eye-line and directional matches were introduced. The film is thus perceived as taking place in an environment around the viewer. * Characters are psychologically individuated, through close-ups on faces and acting methods borrowed from (bourgeois) theater. Psychological depth is prized, and the narrative is driven by character psychology. The audience is therefore invited to interpret the motivations of the characters, and thus involve itself with the film.
==See also== * [[Formalist film theory]]
== References == {{reflist}}
* Bordwell, David (1997). ''On the History of Film Style''. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. Chapter 4.
* Burch, Noël (1973). ''Theory of Film Practice'', trans. Helen R. Lane. New York: Praeger.
[[Category:Film theory]]

{{Unreferenced|date=October 2007}} '''Jenkka''' ['jeŋkːɑ] is a fast [[Culture of Finland|Finnish]] [[partner dance]] originated in Finnish [[folk dance]], the Finnish version of [[Schottische]]. It is danced to the music in [[Time signature|2/4]] or [[4/4 time|4/4]] [[time signature]] of about 140 [[beats per minute]].
Men and women do similar steps. The initial [[dance position]] is the man is to the left of the woman both facing in the direction of the [[line of dance]], with their inner arms on each other's waists. The dancers go forward in a run similar to [[Polka]]: "left-right-left-hop(on the left foot)", "right-left-right-hop". After that they join the free arms, assume the face-to-face closed dance position and proceed with the chain of [[pivot turn]]s stepping "left-right-left-right" or "left-hop-right-hop". The runs of similar steps are normally started at the beginnings of musical phrases.
[[Georg Malmstén]] composed many Jenkkas.
==See also== *[[Letkajenkka]]
{{Finnish folk music}}

{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> |image = |imagesize = | name = Julia Jarcho | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Playwright, Director, Poet, Professor | nationality = American | period = | genre = Experimental | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''Grimly Handsome'' (2013) | signature = | website = [http://minortheater.org Minor Theater] }}
'''Julia Jarcho''' is an American experimental playwright and director and professor of dramatic literature. She is the Artistic Director of Minor Theater, a theater company which produces and debuts her new works. She won the 2013 Obie for Best New American Play for ''Grimly Handsome''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/05/20/obie-awards-honor-detroit-and-grimly-handsome/|title=Obie Awards Honor 'Detroit' and 'Grimly Handsome'|first=Patrick|last=Healy|publisher=NYTimes.com|date=20 May 2013}}</ref> Chief theater critic for ''[[The New York Times]]'' [[Ben Brantley]] has called her “a queen of experimental mayhem.” <ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/19/theater/the-terrifying-review.html|title=Review: ‘The Terrifying’ Has Paranoia and the Feeling Something’s Wrong|first=Ben|last=Brantley|date=19 March 2017|publisher=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
==Background== Jarcho grew up in New York City, where she attended [[Hunter College High School]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/11/23/movies/theater-review-works-by-playwrights-too-young-to-drink.html|title=THEATER REVIEW; Works by Playwrights Too Young to Drink|first=Bruce|last=Weber|date=23 November 2001|publisher=NYTimes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thecrimson.com/article/2002/2/7/soundbites-of-a-generation-in-between/|title=Soundbites of a Generation|publisher=FM: The Harvard Crimson Magazine|first=M. R.|last=Brewster|date=7 February 2002}}</ref> She graduated from Harvard College with a degree in Literature.<ref>{{cite article|url=http://harvardmagazine.com/2003/05/estimable-seniors.html|title=Estimable Seniors|date=1 May 2003|work=Harvard Magazine|issue=May-June 2003}}</ref> Her senior thesis, ''Going on: Wittgenstein's Liveness and the Grammar of Theater'', included the production of an original play, ''Grammar''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hollis.harvard.edu/primo_library/libweb/action/dlDisplay.do?vid=HVD&search_scope=default_scope&docId=HVD_ALEPH009763388&fn=permalink|title=Going on: Wittgenstein's liveness and the grammar of theater|first=Julia|last=Jarcho|date=1 January 2003|publisher=Hollis.harvard.edu}}</ref> She received her PhD from UC Berkeley’s Rhetoric Department in 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rhetoric.berkeley.edu/graduate-program/graduate-placement |title=Placement of Graduate Students | Rhetoric Department | UC Berkeley |website=Rhetoric.berkeley.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-04-25}}</ref>
==Career== Jarcho began her career in experimental theater as a performer, acting in plays by [[Richard Maxwell (director)|Richard Maxwell]] in Downtown New York theaters such as the [[Incubator Arts Project#Ontological Theater (1992-2005)|Ontological Theater]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/06/22/theater/farewell-to-the-second-floor-theater-at-st-marks-church.html|title=Farewell to the Second-Floor Theater at St. Mark’s Church|first=Alexis|last=Soloski|date=19 June 2014|publisher=NYTimes.com}}</ref> and [[Soho Rep]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/04/06/theater/theater-review-drone-on-the-range-adventures-in-the-mild-mild-west.html|title=Drone on the Range: Adventures in the Mild, Mild West|date=6 April 1999|work=The New York Times|first=Peter|last=Marks}}</ref>
===Plays=== Nursery, written when she was a senior at Hunter College High School, was a winner of the Young Playwrights Festival National Playwriting Competition and was performed at the Cherry Lane Theater in 2001.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2001/11/23/movies/theater-review-works-by-playwrights-too-young-to-drink.html|title=Works by Playwrights Too Young to Drink|date=23 November 2001|work=The New York Times|first=Bruce|last=Weber}}</ref>
Her adaptation of [[Alfred Noyes]]’ poem, ''[[The Highwayman (poem)|The Highwayman]]'' was presented at the [[National Theater of the United States of America|NTUSA]] performance space in Brooklyn in December 2004 and published in ''The Best American Short Plays 2005-2006''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/223807521|title=The Best American Short Plays 2005-2006|first1=Barbara|last1=Parisi|first2=David|last2=Ives|first3=Quiara Alegría|last3=Hudes|first4=Jules|last4=Tasca|first5=Pamela|last5=Sneed|first6=Carol K|last6=Mack|first7=Michael|last7=Roderick|first8=Jeni|last8=Mahoney|first9=Dano|last9=Madden|first10=James|last10=Armstrong|first11=Cary|last11=Pepper|first12=Adam|last12=Kraar|first13=Joan|last13=Lipkin|first14=Cara|last14=Restaino|first15=Julia|last15=Jarcho|first16=Murray|last16=Schisgal|date=1 January 2008|publisher=Open WorldCat}}</ref>
''Delmar'' was staged at the Prenzlkasper theater in Berlin, Germany, in October 2005. Jarcho later collaborated with visual artist, Meredith James, who adapted the play as a video installation at the Jack Hanley Gallery.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://meredith-james.com/work/delmar/1 |title=Work : Delmar |publisher=Meredith James |date= |accessdate=2017-04-25}}</ref>
As a member of the playwrights' collective, 13P, Jarcho's ''American Treasure'' was staged at Paradise Factory Theatre in November 2009. ''The New York Times'' called the play, "an odd, dense, oblique but haunting work" and noted that Jarcho is "a remarkably clever, bewitching writer and a master of stylized behavior."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/09/theater/reviews/09american.html|title=Historical Whodunit by Julia Jarcho at Paradise Factory|first=Anita|last=Gates|date=8 December 2009|publisher=NYTimes.com}}</ref>
''Grimly Handsome'' premiered at the Incubator Arts Project in January 2013 as part of the Other Forces Festival and won the Obie for Best New American Play that year. In January 2015 it was remounted at JACK in Brooklyn.
Other productions by Jarcho include: ''Dreamless Land'' which premiered with [[New York City Players]] at the [[Abrons Arts Center]] in November 2011; ''Nomads'', directed by [[Alice Reagan]], was the final play performed at the Incubator Arts Project in June 2014; ''Every Angel is Brutal'', directed by Knud Adams, was part of [[Clubbed Thumb]]'s Summerworks 2016 lineup and staged at the Wild Project.
Her most recent play, ''The Terrifying'', premiered at the Abrons Arts Center in March 2017.
===Style=== The playwright [[Mac Wellman]] described Jarcho’s work as a writer and director as “[[Menippean satire]]...dealing with the whole analysis of what theater is.”<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424127887323485704578255950313410458|title=Every Golden Age Needs a Sage|first=Lizzie|last=Simon|date=21 January 2013|work=WSJ}}{{subscription required}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://playwrightslocal4181.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Every-Golden-Age-Needs-a-Sage-WSJ-2013.pdf|title=Every Golden Age Needs a Sage|first=Lizzie|last=Simon|date=21 January 2013|work=WSJ|via=playwrightslocal.org}}</ref>
Structurally, Jarcho's plays have employed unconventional storytelling techniques<ref name="nytimes.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/11/theater/reviews/julia-jarchos-dreamless-land-review.html|title=Julia Jarcho’s ‘Dreamless Land’ - Review|first=Rachel|last=Saltz|date=10 November 2011|publisher=NYTimes.com}}</ref>—what the ''New Yorker'' and others have called, "non-linear,"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/05/04/reality-show|title=Reality Onstage|date=4 May 2015|work=The New Yorker|first=Hilton|last=Als}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nyunews.com/2015/11/05/professor-playwright-julia-jarcho-combines-academia-and-theater/|title=Professor, playwright Julia Jarcho combines academia and theater|first=Abraham|last=Gross|work=Washington Square News|date=5 November 2015}}</ref> and ''Time Out New York'' and ''New York Theatre Review'' have referred to as "shifting" narratives.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timeout.com/newyork/theater/julia-jarcho-interview-theater-is-fundamentally-embarrassing|title=Julia Jarcho interview: ‘Theater is fundamentally embarrassing’|work=Time Out New York|first=Eliza|last=Bent|date=3 June 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://newyorktheatrereview.blogspot.com/2014/06/teddy-nicholas-on-julia-jarchos-nomads.html|first=Teddy|last=Nicholas|date=9 June 2014|title=Teddy Nicholas on Julia Jarcho’s Nomads at the Incubator Arts Project|work=New York Theatre Review}}</ref> Actors in Jarcho's productions often perform multiple roles to engage audiences in questions of coherent selfhood and stable identity.<ref name="nytimes.com"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timeout.com/newyork/theater/grimly-handsome|title=Grimly Handsome|date=9 January 2013|work=Time Out New York|first=Helen|last=Shaw}}</ref><ref name="auto"/>
==Works== ===As playwright and director=== * ''The Terrifying'' (Minor Theater, March–April 2017) * ''Grimly Handsome'' (Incubator Arts Project, January 2013 and JACK, January 2015) * ''Dreamless Land'' (New York City Players, November 2011) * ''American Treasure'' (13P, New York, November 2009 and Bay Area Playwrights Festival, May 2009) * ''Aria Da Capo'' (Target Margin, New York, June 2009) * ''All I Do Is Dream Of You'' (Festival 100º/Sophiensaele, Berlin, February 2006) * ''The Highwayman'' (NTUSA performance space, New York, December 2004)
===As playwright=== * ''Every Angel is Brutal'', directed by Knud Adams (Clubbed Thumb, May 2016) * ''Nomads'', directed by Alice Reagan (Incubator Arts Project, May/June 2014) * ''A Small Hole'', directed by Alice Reagan (Performance Lab 115, NYC Fringe Festival, August 2006) * ''Nursery'', directed by Brett W. Reynolds (Young Playwrights Festival/Cherry Lane Theater, New York, Fall 2001; directed by [[Mark Ravenhill]] at UC Davis, Fall 2005)
==Awards and honors== Jarcho is the recipient of a Doris Duke Impact Award, an Obie for Best New American Play, a Berrilla Kerr Award for Excellence in Playwriting, and a Sarah Verdone Writing Award. She has been a resident at the Eugene O’Neill Playwrights Conference, the Playwrights Foundation, and at the Macdowell Colony.
==Teaching and research== Jarcho is a professor in New York University’s Dramatic Literature program, where she teaches courses on modernism, drama, playwrighting, and literary and critical theory. Her first academic book is ''Writing and the Modern Stage: Theater Beyond Drama'' (2017).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.fas.nyu.edu/object/juliajarcho.html |title=Jarcho, Julia | English | New York University |website=English.fas.nyu.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-04-25}}</ref>
==Publications== * Nursery in ''Rush Hour II: Bad Boys'' {{ISBN|0-38-573033-0}} * The Highwayman in ''The Best American Short Plays 2005-2006'' {{ISBN|978-1-557-83713-4}} * American Treasure in ''{{WorldCat|oclc=812534950|name=13P: The Complete Plays}}'' * ''Minor Theater: Three Plays'' {{ISBN|0-98-973936-8}} * ''Writing and the Modern Stage: Theater Beyond Drama'' {{ISBN|978-1-107-13235-1}} * ''Grimly Handsome'' {{ISBN|978-1-350-06636-6}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://minortheater.org/ Minor Theater] * [http://english.fas.nyu.edu/object/juliajarcho.html NYU Faculty Biography]

'''Kara Nova''' is a pole acrobat in the [[San Francisco]] Bay area, [[California]].
== Career ==
Kara Nova moved to San Francisco from Ohio when she was 18. She performs regularly as a pole acrobat in venues along the West Coast with burlesque troupe ''Hubba Hubba Revue'', and with avant-garde cabaret circus troupe ''The Vau de Vire Society''.<ref name="Oakland Tribune">{{cite web | url=http://www.insidebayarea.com/oaklandtribune/localnews/ci_19050122?source=rss | title=Oakland Tribune | publisher=Oakland Tribune Press | work=Artist's Path Leads to the Pole | date=October 6, 2011 | accessdate=November 14, 2011 | author=Tietz, Janko | pages=A5}}</ref>
In July 2011, Kara Nova featured in the Hubba Hubba Revue's poster as pole acrobat/saint being burnt at the stake, with the [[burlesque]] captions "Old Time Religion" and "Plate 15. Kara Nova. Foxy's Book of Martyrs" - a play on [[Foxe's Book of Martyrs]].<ref>[http://www.dnalounge.com/flyers/2011/07/22.html DNA Lounge] 'Old Time Religion' Flyer 22 July 2011. Retrieved 14 November 2011</ref>
== Reception ==
According to reviewers, Kara Nova is an exceptionally strong acrobat and an impressive performer. [[Der Spiegel]] commented (in German) ''"Strip Clubs? Topless bars? Cheap Callgirls? Forget it. Pole Dance has long been a trend sport, and Kara Nova is one of the best dancers in the United States. The 22-year-old is all muscle, and performs feats which are frivolous, lascivious - but never vulgar."'' <ref>[http://www.spiegel.de/panorama/0,1518,792243,00.html Der Spiegel (in German)]"Poledance-Star Nova: Mädel von der Stange." ('Pole Girl') Janko Tietz, San Francisco. 21 October 2011. </ref> [[SF Weekly]] wrote ''"Kara Nova's 'Burned at the Cross' pole dance routine is a must see."'' <ref>[http://www.sfweekly.com/slideshow/july-2011-the-month-in-sf-weekly-pictures-33859499/ SF Weekly] July 2011. Retrieved 14 November 2011</ref>

'''Ken Testi''' is [[Great Britain|British]] [[entrepreneur]] most notable for his involvement with the bands [[Queen (band)|Queen]] and [[Deaf School]] and with the Liverpool music venue [[Eric's Club]].
==Biography== In the mid-1960s whilst at school, Testi began promoting shows in venues as diverse as scout huts, youth clubs, schools, pubs and civic halls.<ref> {{cite book |last=Florek|first=Jaki |year=2001 |title=Bridge Over Muddy Waters |publisher=Feeedback |isbn=978-0-9540326-0-9 }}</ref> In the summer of 1969, with a band formed at school, he went to London where he met Freddie Bulsara. A few weeks later Bulsara appeared on stage for the first time, fronting the band Testi had taken to London. Bulsara changed the band’s name from [[Ibex (band)|Ibex]] to Wreckage and later changed his own name to [[Freddie Mercury]].<ref>Gunn, Jacky & Jenkins, Jim (1992). Queen: As It Began. Sidgwick & Jackson Ltd. {{ISBN|978-0-283-06052-6}}</ref>
During 1970, as a college social secretary, Testi continued to follow Mercury’s progress with Roger Taylor and Brian May in the newly formed [[Queen (band)|Queen]] and arranged three shows for the band; at a youth club in Potters Bar, at St Helens College of Technology and at Liverpool’s Cavern Club.<ref> {{cite book |last=Jackson|first=Laura |year=1994 |title=Queen and I: The Brian May Story |publisher=Smith Gryphon |isbn=978-1-85685-099-5 }}</ref> Testi returned to London and spent 1971 encouraging Queen and generating interest from record companies.<ref> {{cite book |last=Blake|first=Mark |year=2010 |title=Is This the Real Life? The Untold Story of Queen |publisher=Aurum |isbn=978-1-84513-659-8 }}</ref>
In mid-1972 Testi returned to Merseyside, working with local musicians until 1974 when he met members of a band from Liverpool College of Art who had taken their name from the building where they rehearsed – [[Deaf School]]. Deaf School became the spark that ignited a creative, musical explosion in Liverpool which had seen scant original musical output since The Beatles.<ref> {{cite book |last=du Noyer|first=Paul |year=2004 |title=Liverpool - Wondrous Place: From the Cavern to the Capital of Culture |publisher=Virgin Books |isbn=978-0-7535-0840-4 }}</ref>
During two years of tour management with Deaf School, Testi formed an alliance with Roger Eagle. The two first met in the 1960s at the Magic Village in Manchester. Together they established [[Eric's Club]] in Mathew Street, Liverpool in 1976. The first band to play was Deaf School, followed by many of the leading acts of the day: [[The Stranglers]], [[The Runaways]], [[The Sex Pistols]], [[The Damned (band)|The Damned]], [[Elvis Costello]], [[The Police]], [[Ian Dury and the Blockheads]], [[Nick Lowe]], [[Dave Edmunds]], [[The Clash]], [[The Ramones]] and [[Talking Heads]], amongst others.<ref> {{cite book |last=Cope|first=Julian |year=1994 |title=Head-on: Memories of the Liverpool Punk Scene and the Story of the Teardrop Explodes, 1976-82 |publisher=Head Heritage |isbn=978-0-9526719-0-9 }}</ref>
Before it closed in March 1980, many new local acts had been encouraged to take to the stage for the first time including [[Jayne Casey]], [[Bill Drummond]], [[Ian Broudie]] and [[Holly Johnson]] ([[Big in Japan (band)|Big in Japan]]), [[Paul Rutherford (singer)|Paul Rutherford]] and [[Budgie (drummer)|Budgie]] ([[The Spitfire Boys]]) and [[Pete Wylie]].<ref> {{cite book |last1=Florek|first1=Jaki |last2=Whelan|first2=Paul |year=2009 |title=Liverpool Eric's - all the best clubs are downstairs, everybody knows that . . . |publisher=Feeedback |isbn=978-0-9540326-2-3 }}</ref> In the 1980s, the UK and international record charts were dominated by talent that had emerged from Eric’s including, [[Frankie Goes to Hollywood]], [[The KLF|KLF]], [[The Lightning Seeds]], [[The Teardrop Explodes]], [[Echo & the Bunnymen]] and [[Dead or Alive (band)|Dead or Alive]].<ref> {{cite web |publisher=Museum of Liverpool |url=http://www.liverpoolmuseums.org.uk/mol/exhibitions/erics |title=Spotlight on Eric's Club |accessdate=1 December 2011 }}</ref>
In 1988 Testi persuaded Deaf School to reform for a series of shows, from which Clive Langer produced a live album, ''2nd Coming: Liverpool '88''. In 2008 Testi produced an Eric’s Show at Liverpool Academy featuring acts from the club.<ref> {{cite web |work=Liverpool.com |url=http://www.liverpool.com/features/eric-s-legends-back-on-stage-in-liverpool.html |title=Eric's legends back on stage in Liverpool |date=27 July 2008 |accessdate=1 December 2011 }}</ref> In the same year Liverpool’s Everyman Theatre produced “Eric’s, The Musical”.<ref> {{cite news |last=Cottrell Boyce|first=Frank |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2008/sep/23/musicals.popandrock |title='We were the guinea pigs of punk' |work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |date=23 September 2008 |accessdate=1 December 2011 }}</ref>
Testi currently runs a company called Eric's Productions Limited, where he produces a number of shows each year for Deaf School, and their celebrity guests who regularly include [[Suggs (singer)|Suggs]] and [[Lee Thompson (saxophonist)|Lee Thompson]] ([[Madness (band)|Madness]]), [[Kevin Rowland]] ([[Dexy's Midnight Runners]]) and Ian Broudie ([[Lightning Seeds]]).<ref> {{cite news |last=Simpson|first=Dave |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/jul/21/catalyst-bands-ruthless-rap-assassins |title='Catalyst bands': What do you mean, you've never heard of them? |work=The Guardian |location=London |date=21 July 2011 |accessdate=1 December 2011 }}</ref>

Australia
Zambia | language = English }} '''''Killing Heat''''' (released in Sweden as ''Gräset sjunger'') is a 1981 film based on [[Doris Lessing|Doris Lessing's]] 1950 novel ''[[The Grass Is Singing]]''. It stars [[Karen Black]] and [[John Thaw]] and was filmed in [[Zambia]] and [[Sweden]]. The film was released in Zimbabwe as ''The Grass is Singing''. Apart from the change of the title, possibly to pander to the US market for violence, the urban life depicted in the film would not have existed in Livingstone in the 1960s, or the 1940s for that matter. The film's interiors were reportedly filmed in Sweden, whereas the exteriors were shot in Zambia. The film deals with the issues of colonialism, the white man's role in [[Africa]], and the relationships between the races and genders. The cultural differences between the races also play a cryptic part in the storyline - some aspects of which will be opaque to viewers without local knowledge. Possibly the film expects viewers to be familiar with the novel. There may be an actual case which inspired the novel. == Plot == The film purportedly takes place in [[South Africa]] in the 1960s (unlike the novel which was set in Southern Rhodesia pre-1950). Mary, a city woman, marries a farmer named Dick Turner. Mary leaves the comfortable familiarity of her urban life and goes to live on Dick's struggling farm. Mary has little experience handling Africans as servants or employees and is harsh and tactless in her treatment of the African farm workers. Mary runs away by herself (to the town of Livingstone, crossing the bridge at Victoria Falls by train - which takes her into what was pre-1964 still Northern Rhodesia), only to find that she cannot get her old job back, and has nowhere to take permanent refuge and no means of financial support. She returns to the farm. Mary slowly becomes insane and breaks the Rhodesian taboo of inter-racial over-familiarity with the African houseboy, Moses. After Mary and Moses are accidentally observed by a newly appointed farm manager in the act of taking what would be considered liberties, Dick decides to send Mary away from the farm. Learning of Mary's forthcoming departure, Moses murders Mary during a rainstorm. Moses is arrested by the police and led off in handcuffs. {{cite web|url=http://petermalone.misacor.org.au/tiki-index.php?page=Grass%20is%20Singing,%20The|title=: Grass is Singing, The|publisher=}} == Cast == * [[Karen Black]] as Mary Turner *[[John Thaw]] as Dick Turner *[[John Kani]] as Moses *[[Patrick Mynhardt]] as Charlie Muller *[[John Moulder Brown]] as Tony Marston *[[Margaret Heale]] as Ellen Muller ==References== == External links == * {{IMDb title|0084033|Killing Heat}} [[Category:1981 films]] [[Category:Swedish films]] [[Category:Films based on British novels]] [[category:Adultery in films]] [[Category:Films set in the 1940s]] [[Category:Films set in Rhodesia]] [[Category:Films set in the British Empire]] [[Category:Zambian films]] [[Category:Zimbabwean films]] [[Category:1980s drama films]] {{1980s-drama-film-stub}} {{British-Empire-stub}} {{Sweden-film-stub}}

{{Use Indian English|date=September 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = Naam Shabana | image = Naam Shabana Poster.jpg | alt = The poster features Taapsee Pannu running and Sniper-rifle aim-pointer appears on her. At bottom appears title of the film. Images of rest star-cast appears at the top. | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Shivam Nair]] | producer = {{ubl|[[Neeraj Pandey]]|Aruna Bhatia}} | writer = Neeraj Pandey | screenplay = Neeraj Pandey | based on = {{based on|Character ''Shabana Khan'' from film ''[[Baby (2015 Hindi film)|Baby]]''|[[Neeraj Pandey]]}} | starring = {{ubl|[[Taapsee Pannu]]|[[Akshay Kumar]]|[[Prithviraj Sukumaran]]|[[Manoj Bajpayee]]|[[Anupam Kher]]}} | music = {{ubl|[[Rochak Kohli]]|[[Meet Bros]]|[[Sanjoy Chowdhury]] ([[Film score|Background score]])}} | cinematography = Sudheer Palsane | editing = Praveen Kathikuloth | studio = {{ubl|[[Plan C Studios]]|Cape Of Good Films}} | distributor = [[Reliance Entertainment]] | released = {{film date|2017|3|31|df=1|ref1=<ref name="Indian Express release"/>}} | runtime = 147 minutes | country = [[India]] | language = [[Hindi]] | budget = {{INRConvert|15|c}}<ref name="IE budget"/> | gross = <!--Do not remove.-->{{Estimation}}<!--per WT:ICTF consensus.-->{{INRConvert|56.06|c}}<ref name="BH Naam Shabana gross">{{cite web|url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/news/box-office-special-features/box-office-worldwide-collections-day-wise-break-naam-shabana/|title=Box Office: Worldwide collections and day wise break up of Naam Shabana - Bollywood Hungama|first=Bollywood|last=Hungama|date=1 April 2017|publisher=|accessdate=17 April 2017}}</ref> }} '''''Naam Shabana''''' ({{lang-en|The name is Shabana|italics=yes}}) is a 2017 Indian [[Action film|action]] [[Spy film|spy]]-[[Thriller (genre)|thriller]] film directed by [[Shivam Nair]] and produced by [[Neeraj Pandey]] and Aruna Bhatia. It is a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] from the 2015 film ''[[Baby (2015 Hindi film)|Baby]]'' with [[Taapsee Pannu]] reprising her role as Shabana.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-naam-shabana-is-spin-off-not-prequel-to-baby-taapsee-pannu-2353190 |title='Naam Shabana' is spin-off, not prequel to 'Baby' Taapsee Pannu |date=15 March 2017 |publisher=[[DNA India]]}}</ref> [[Akshay Kumar]] and [[Prithviraj Sukumaran]] play important supporting roles in the film.{{efn|name=fn3|Akshay Kumar, Anupam Kher, Danny Denzongpa and Madhurima Tuli remains the only cast who reprised their role from the previous film.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-naam-shabana-trailer-taapsee-pannu-dares-to-do-what-no-other-man-does-in-this-action-packed-film-2319080 |title='Naam Shabana' Trailer: Taapsee Pannu DARES to do what no other man does in this action packed film! |last=Pandey |first=Prachita |date=10 February 2017 |publisher=[[DNA India]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://movies.ndtv.com/bollywood/naam-shabana-why-akshay-kumar-has-lesser-portions-than-taapsee-pannu-in-baby-spin-off-1674934 |title=Naam Shabana: Why Akshay Kumar Has Lesser Portions Than Taapsee Pannu In Baby Spin-Off |last=Shiksha |first=Shruthi |date=29 March 2017 |publisher=[[NDTV]]}}</ref>}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/meet-naam-shabanas-strong-and-interesting-mix-of-characters/articleshow/57917747.cms|title=Meet 'Naam Shabana’s' strong and interesting mix of characters}}</ref> The film is dubbed into [[Telugu language|Telugu]] and [[Tamil language|Tamil]] languages and was released on 31 March 2017. The Tamil title was ‘Naanthan Shabana’.<ref name="Indian Express release">{{Cite web |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/telugu/naam-shabana-taapsee-pannu-film-nene-shabana-naanthaan-shabana-watch-tamil-telugu-trailers-4544755/ |title=Naam Shabana: Taapsee Pannu shares Tamil, Telugu trailers, leaving fans asking for more. |date=26 February 2017 |publisher=[[The Indian Express]]}}</ref> One day after its release in Pakistan the film was banned in the country for being an Indian perspective.<ref name="Pakistan-ban">{{cite news|last1=Jha|first1=Subhash K|title=Now, Naam Shabana banned in Pakistan|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/entertainment/bollywood/090417/now-naam-shabana-banned-in-pakistan.html|work=Deccan Chronicle|date=Apr 9, 2017}}</ref>
==Plot== The film begins with two Indian agents working under Ranvir Singh ([[Manoj Bajpai]]) chasing an international arms dealer Mikhail ([[Prithviraj Sukumaran]]), who has been on the radar of several intelligence agencies, but instead he kills them both and escapes. A year later Shabana Khan ([[Taapsee Pannu]]) a college student who is also a Judo fighter is being followed by Indian agency as a potential recruit. One of Shabana's friends, Jai ([[Taher Shabbir]]) who likes Shabana, and always tries to hit on her, asks her on a date a day before his birthday, she agrees to go with him on the date and there he confesses his love for her. During the date he asks her about her past, and Shabana tells him that she had been kept in juvenile detention for killing her abusive father who used to physically assault her mother. During their bike ride home Shabana is a victim of [[eve teasing]] from a group of four drunk men in a Jeep, with the exchange turning into a physical altercation resulting in Jai getting killed and the assailants running away. Soon after, Shabana receives a call from an unknown number asking if she wants to avenge her lover's death. The unknown caller agrees to help her terminate the killer in exchange for Shabana joining a secret agency. Shabana agrees to this and accordingly receives information on the killer's whereabouts, and the agents aid her in killing them. Shabana then goes to Goa, to the same hotel where the main culprit who killed Jai was staying. As instructed, Shabana enters his room killing him and later escapes with the help of Ajay Singh ([[Akshay Kumar]]). The unknown caller is then revealed to be agent Ranvir Singh.
Following this Shabana is recruited into the secret agency on a trial basis, wherein she is receives extensive training in physical fitness and fighting techniques. The story then focuses on global arms dealer and supplier Mikhail. Three Indian agents then track down Tony, Mikhail's right hand. During interrogation Tony tips them off as to the identity of a German doctor who has surgically changed Mikhail's face. By the time the agency contacts the doctor to find out how Mikhail looks now Tony kills all three agents and escapes, revealing that he himself is Mikhail. Ranvir Singh gets the tip that Mikhail is planning another plastic surgery to change his face. This time Shabana is sent to kill Mikhail with the help of Ajay Singh and Om Prakash Shukla ([[Anupam Kher]]). Shabana enters the adjacent operation theater disguised as a patient, and after getting rid of Mikhail's private security is about to kill Mikhail in the [[operating theater]]. To her surprise he is awake as he had refused to take general anesthesia during the operation. After quite a tussle, where Mikhail almost strangles Shabana, she finally manages to kill Mikhail and once again escape from the police with the help of Ajay.
==Cast== *[[Taapsee Pannu]] as Shabana Khan *[[Akshay Kumar]] as Ajay Singh Rajput (extended cameo) *[[Prithviraj Sukumaran]] as Tony / Mikhail *[[Manoj Bajpayee]] as Ranvir Singh *[[Virendra Saxena]] as Cableman *[[Anupam Kher]] as Om Prakash Shukla *[[Danny Denzongpa]] as Feroz Ali Khan *[[Arjun Singh Shekhawat]] as Prashant *[[Madhurima Tuli]] as Anjali Singh Rajput *[[Murali Sharma]] as Mr. Gupta *[[Bhaskar B V]] as Srini, RAW Agent *[[Zakir Hussain (actor)|Zakir Hussain]] as Aseem Gupta, a RAW agent *[[Bhuvan Arora]] as Karan *[[Taher Shabbir]] as Jai *[[Natasha Rastogi]] as Farida Begum Khan, Shabana's mother *[[Manav Vij]] as Ravi, a RAW agent *[[Mohan Kapoor]] as a College professor *[[Elli Avram]] as Sona, Tony's friend Malik's girlfriend. (Cameo) *[[Shibani Dandekar]] as special appearance in song "Baby Besharam" *Aparna Upadhyay as Jai's mother
==Production== ===Casting and development=== [[Taapsee Pannu]] was trained in [[mixed martial arts]] and Judo along with [[Krav Maga]] for her role in the film.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/naam-shabana-guess-who-trained-taapsee-pannu-in-martial-arts-for-the-film/story-dYC0TUgzqtTOtNXskZuOnL.html |title=Naam Shabana: Guess who trained Taapsee Pannu in martial arts for the film? |date=21 March 2017 |publisher=[[Hindustan Times]]}}</ref> In October 2016, [[Prithviraj Sukumaran]] joined the cast of the film and had shot for a cameo role.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/malayalam/Prithviraj-heads-to-Malaysia-for-cameo-in-Naam-Shabana/articleshow/54765011.cms |title=Prithviraj heads to Malaysia for cameo in Naam Shabana |last=Sidhardhan |first=Sanjith |date=10 October 2016 |publisher=[[Times of India]]}}</ref> [[Akshay Kumar]] was signed to play an extended cameo in the film, reprising his role from the previous film.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/hindi/2017/mar/09/cameos-to-look-out-for-this-year-1579200.html |title=Cameos to look out for this year |date=9 March 2017 |publisher=[[The New Indian Express]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.mid-day.com/articles/taapsee-pannu-akshay-kumar-extended-cameo-naam-shabana-role-reversal-bollywood-news/17992187 |title=Taapsee Pannu talks about Akshay Kumar's extended cameo in 'Naam Shabana': I like this role reversal |last=Dedhia |first=Sonil |date=14 February 2017 |publisher=[[Mid Day]]}}</ref> [[Anupam Kher]] was signed to play the role of a [[Software agent|technical agent]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/anupam-kher-naam-shabana-taapsee-pannu-akshay-kumar-manoj-bajpayee-naam-shukla-4577336/ |title=Anupam Kher: After Naam Shabana, I hope they make Naam Shukla |last=Kameshwari |first=A |date=20 March 2017 |publisher=[[The Indian Express]]}}</ref> French stuntman [[Cyril Raffaelli]] was signed to choreograph the stunts of the film.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/hollywood-stunt-director-for-taapsee-pannu/articleshow/56661983.cms |title=Hollywood stunt director for Taapsee Pannu |last=Coutinho |first=Natasha |date=29 January 2017 |publisher=[[Times of India]]}}</ref> For the preparation of the role of Pannu's character as a spy, producer [[Neeraj Pandey]] took guidance from full-time consultant, an ex-intelligence officer.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/naam-shabana-based-on-a-real-life-spy-and-her-operations-in-malaysia/story-T6QndfJ3xZOSm5ZewKIoCN.html |title=Naam Shabana based on a real-life spy and her operations in Malaysia? |date=18 March 2017 |publisher=[[Hindustan Times]]}}</ref> [[Varun Dhawan]] was also rumored to be a part of the film, however the actor claimed later that he is not the part of the film.{{efn|name=fn1|Initially, it was rumoured that Dhawan was to be a part the film which is not actually sequel.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/varun-dhawan-to-work-with-akshay-kumar-in-baby-sequel/ |title=Varun Dhawan to work with Akshay Kumar in ‘Baby’ sequel? |last=Sharma |first=Sarika |date=10 February 2015 |publisher=[[The Indian Express]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/bollywood/varun-dhawan-to-work-in-sequel-to-akshay-kumar-s-baby/story-8fIjUCPhdC0DAYcz5ffvCM.html |title=Varun Dhawan to work in sequel to Akshay Kumar's Baby? |last=Singh |first=Prashant |date=10 February 2015 |publisher=[[Hindustan Times]]}}</ref> Dhawan later cleared about his involvement and being not a part of the film.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/entertainment/report-varun-dhawan-not-a-part-of-akshay-kumar-s-baby-sequel-2060394 |title=Varun Dhawan not a part of Akshay Kumar's 'Baby' sequel? |date=12 February 2015 |publisher=[[DNA India]]}}</ref>}}<!--Do not remove the mentioned footnote-->
===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] of the film's first schedule began on September 2016 in Malaysia, where Kumar and Pannu shot for stunt sequences.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/Taapsee-Pannu-starrer-Naam-Shabana-shoot-begins/articleshow/54311309.cms |title=Taapsee Pannu-starrer 'Naam Shabana' shoot begins |date=28 January 2017 |publisher=[[Times of India]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/bollywood/akshay-kumar-taapsee-pannu-shoot-for-naam-shabana-in-malaysia-3082691/ |title=Akshay Kumar, Taapsee Pannu shoot for Naam Shabana in Malaysia |date=14 October 2016 |publisher=[[The Indian Express]]}}</ref> Filming of the first schedule was completed in late October 2016.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/entertainment/bollywood/281016/akshay-kumar-taapsee-pannu-wrap-up-first-leg-of-shoot-for-naam-shabana.html |title=Akshay Kumar, Taapsee Pannu wrap up first leg of shoot for 'Naam Shabana' |date=28 October 2016 |publisher=[[Deccan Chronicle]]}}</ref> The film's second schedule was started on November 2016 in Mumbai.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/news/features/check-taapsee-pannu-shoots-naam-shabana-streets-mumbai/ |title=Check out: Taapsee Pannu shoots for Naam Shabana on the streets of Mumbai |date=9 November 2016 |publisher=[[Bollywood Hungama]]}}</ref> The shooting of the film was wrapped up in February 2017.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.bollywoodhungama.com/news/features/check-team-naam-shabana-wraps-shoot/ |title=Check out: Team Naam Shabana wraps its shoot |date=22 February 2017 |publisher=[[Bollywood Hungama]]}}</ref>
===Budget and collections=== The film was produced on a budget of {{INR}}15 crore.<ref name="IE budget">{{cite web|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/naam-shabana-box-office-collection-day-5-taapsee-pannu-film-4599400/|title=Naam Shabana box office collection day 5: Taapsee Pannu film earns Rs 23. 80 crores|date=4 April 2017|publisher=|accessdate=5 April 2017}}</ref> Its first day gross was approximately {{INR}}5.12 crore, and the film finished its first weekend with an estimated gross of {{INR}}18.76 crore.<ref name="BH Naam Shabana gross" />
==Soundtrack== The songs of the film are composed by [[Rochak Kohli]] and [[Meet Bros]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.spotboye.com/bollywood/news/akshay-ropes-in-rochak-kohli-and-meet-bros-for-naam-shabana/584059bdd3028a6738dcd68b |title=Akshay Ropes In Rochak Kohli And Meet Bros For Naam Shabana|last=Ingle|first=Dhairya|date=2 December 2016|publisher=[[9X Media|SpotBoyE]]}}</ref> Lyrics are written by [[Manoj Muntashir]] and [[Kumaar]] and released by [[Super Cassettes Industries T-Series|T-Series]]. The [[film score]] is composed by [[Sanjoy Chowdhury]].
{{Track listing | headline = Track listing | extra_column = Singer(s) | total_length = 16:30 | title1 = Rozana | lyrics1 = [[Manoj Muntashir]] | music1 = [[Rochak Kohli]] | extra1 = [[Shreya Ghoshal]] | length1 = 4:34 | title2 = Zinda | lyrics2 = Manoj Muntashir | music2 = Rochak Kohli | extra2 = [[Sunidhi Chauhan]] | length2 = 4:00 | title3 = [[Zubi Zubi]] | lyrics3 = Manoj Muntashir | music3 = Rochak Kohli | extra3 = [[Sukriti Kakar]], Rochak Kohli | length3 = 4:10 | title4 = Dil Hua Besharam | lyrics4 = [[Kumaar]] | music4 = [[Meet Bros]] | extra4 = [[Aditi Singh Sharma]] | length4 = 3:46 }}
==Response== Shubhra Gupta of ''The Indian Express'' wrote, "What does come as a surprise, however, is just how much of a drag the film is. Except for a few stray sequences in which the limber Taapsee Pannu goes after the bad guys, and the ones in which co-star Akshay Kumar moves in to demonstrate how the big boys do it, there is nothing either novel or interesting about the film."<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gupta|first1=Shubhra|title=Naam Shabana movie review: Taapsee Pannu’s action, Akshay Kumar are highlights of this film|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/entertainment/movie-review/naam-shabana-movie-review-taapsee-pannu-akshay-kumar-star-rating-4591275/|work= Indian Express|publisher=The Indian Express|accessdate=30 March 2017}}</ref>
On April 9, 2017 the film was banned in [[Pakistan]] by its [[Central Board of Film Censors]].<ref name="Pakistan-ban"/><ref name="financialexpress-ban">{{cite news|title=Naam Shabana banned in Pakistan, Censor Board says scenes related to terrorism ‘not fit’|url=http://www.financialexpress.com/entertainment/naam-shabana-banned-in-pakistan-censor-board-says-scenes-related-to-terrorism-not-fit/621424/|work=Financial Express|date=April 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Pakistan bans 'Naam Shabana' a day after its release|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/hindi/bollywood/news/pakistan-bans-naam-shabana-a-day-after-its-release/articleshow/58094575.cms|work=The Times of India|date=Apr 9, 2017}}</ref><ref name="indiatoday">{{cite news|last1=Ghosh|first1=Samrudhi|title=Naam Shabana withdrawn from Pakistani theatres because terrorism theme too sensitive?|url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/naam-shabana-pakistan-terrorism-taapsee-pannu-akshay-kumar/1/924303.html|work=India Today|date=April 9, 2017}}</ref> It had been shown in Pakistan starting on March 31, 2017 as long as certain scenes with a terrorism theme were cut.<ref name="financialexpress-ban"/> One day after an Islamabad theatre showed an uncut version the film was banned from all theatres in the country.<ref name="indiatoday"/>
